DOC.HEAD: Engineers Report No Cracking in Military Nuclear Reactor
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department after months of study has dismissed the possibility of any cracking in one of the three reactors at the Savannah River nuclear weapons complex. Studies of the two other reactors are planned for next year. The determination of no cracking in P reactor is a major gain for the department, which is in the midst of a $1.66 billion program to repair and modernize the three reactors. They have been closed for more than a year for safety reasons. Discovery of cracking in any of the reactor vessels likely would put them permanently out of service since the 35-year-old vessels are virtually irreplaceable. The Savannah River reactors are the nation's only source of tritium, a radioactive gas used in nuclear warheads. Tritium decays at a rate of 5.5 percent a year, so supplies in warheads must be replenished periodically or the bombs cease to function. Barring any unforeseen problems such as vessel cracking, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins hopes to restart K reactor by next fall; the second, L reactor, by December 1990, and the third, P reactor, in the spring of 1991. The Savannah River complex is located near Aiken, S.C. Last September, engineers of Westinghouse Savannah River Co., which runs the plant under an Energy Department contract, began using a sophisticated new technology called ultrasonic testing to check for cracks in the reactor vessels. Westinghouse and Watkins initially said completion of the tests was not a precondition to restarting the reactors, but Watkins changed his mind in late September after Westinghouse reported a potential sign of cracking in P reactor. A few days later, he announced that the irregularity was an existing weld repair that would not affect the reactor's safety. The P reactor testing was completed Oct. 30. In Friday's report on results of ultrasonic testing at P reactor, Westinghouse said there were no signs of cracking, although several irregularities were found. It said these irregularities were determined to be weld repairs done during manufacture of the vessel, or other harmless abnormalities. ``In no case do any of these findings represent a concern with respect to the structural integrity of the tank,'' the report said. In ultrasonic testing, high-frequency sound waves are passed through the reactor vessel walls, and any abnormalities, including cracks, show up as breaks in the waves. Becky Apter, a Westinghouse spokeswoman, said Friday that ultrasonic testing at K reactor was scheduled to begin in mid-January, but that it probably would be set back a week or 10 days because of delays in other work at the reactor.
